methods.name: File
methods.description: A File object is created from your Bucket object using storage/bucket#file.

methods.name: acl
methods.description:
Google Cloud Storage uses access control lists (ACLs) to manage object and bucket access. ACLs are the mechanism you use to share objects with other users and allow other users to access your buckets and objects.

An ACL consists of one or more entries, where each entry grants permissions to a scope. Permissions define the actions that can be performed against an object or bucket (for example, READ or WRITE); the scope defines who the permission applies to (for example, a specific user or group of users).

For more detailed information, see About Access Control Lists.

The acl object on a File instance provides methods to get you a list of the ACLs defined on your bucket, as well as set, update, and delete them.

examples.caption: Make a file publicly readable.

methods.name: copy
methods.description: Copy this file to another file. By default, this will copy the file to the same bucket, but you can choose to copy it to another Bucket by providing either a Bucket or File object.

examples.caption: You can pass in a variety of types for the destination. For all of the below examples, assume we are working with the following Bucket and File objects.
examples.code:
var bucket = storage.bucket('my-bucket');
var file = bucket.file('my-image.png');

examples.caption: If you pass in a string for the destination, the file is copied to its current bucket, under the new name provided.
If you pass in a Bucket object, the file will be copied to that bucket using the same name.
If you pass in a File object, you have complete control over the new bucket and filename.

exceptions.description: If the destination file is not provided.

methods.name: createReadStream
methods.description:
Create a readable stream to read the contents of the remote file. It can be piped to a writable stream or listened to for 'data' events to read a file's contents.

In the unlikely event there is a mismatch between what you downloaded and the version in your Bucket, your error handler will receive an error with code "CONTENT_DOWNLOAD_MISMATCH". If you receive this error, the best recourse is to try downloading the file again.

NOTE: Readable streams will emit the complete event when the file is fully downloaded.

examples.caption:
Downloading a File

The example below demonstrates how we can reference a remote file, then pipe its contents to a local file. This is effectively creating a local backup of your remote data.
To limit the downloaded data to only a byte range, pass an options object.

params.name: options.validation
params.description: • Possible values: "md5", "crc32c", or false. By default, data integrity is validated with an MD5 checksum for maximum reliability, falling back to CRC32c when an MD5 hash wasn't returned from the API. CRC32c will provide better performance with less reliability. You may also choose to skip validation completely, however this is not recommended.

params.name: options.start
params.description: • A byte offset to begin the file's download from. Default is 0. NOTE: Byte ranges are inclusive; that is, options.start = 0 and options.end = 999 represent the first 1000 bytes in a file or object. NOTE: when specifying a byte range, data integrity is not available.

params.name: options.end
params.description: • A byte offset to stop reading the file at. NOTE: Byte ranges are inclusive; that is, options.start = 0 and options.end = 999 represent the first 1000 bytes in a file or object. NOTE: when specifying a byte range, data integrity is not available.

methods.name: createWriteStream
methods.description:
Create a writable stream to overwrite the contents of the file in your bucket.

A File object can also be used to create files for the first time.

NOTE: Writable streams will emit the complete event when the file is fully uploaded.

examples.caption:
Uploading a File

Now, consider a case where we want to upload a file to your bucket. You have the option of using storage/bucket#upload, but that is just a convenience method which will do the following.

Uploading a File with Metadata

One last case you may run into is when you want to upload a file to your bucket and set its metadata at the same time. Like above, you can use storage/bucket#upload to do this, which is just a wrapper around the following.

params.name: options.resumable
params.description: • Force a resumable upload. NOTE: When working with streams, the file format and size is unknown until it's completely consumed. Because of this, it's best for you to be explicit for what makes sense given your input. Read more about resumable uploads here.

params.name: options.validation
params.description: • Possible values: "md5", "crc32c", or false. By default, data integrity is validated with an MD5 checksum for maximum reliability. CRC32c will provide better performance with less reliability. You may also choose to skip validation completely, however this is not recommended.

examples.code: file.delete(function(err) {});

methods.name: download
methods.description: Convenience method to download a file into memory or to a local destination.

examples.caption: Download a file into memory. The contents will be available as the second argument in the demonstration below, contents.
examples.code: file.download(function(err, contents) {});

examples.caption: Download a file to a local destination.

params.name: options
params.description: • Optional configuration. The arguments match those passed to storage/file#createReadStream.

params.name: options.destination
params.description: • Local file path to write the file's contents to.

examples.code: file.getMetadata(function(err, metadata) {});

methods.name: getSignedUrl
methods.description:
Get a signed URL to allow limited time access to the file.

Reference.

params.name: options.contentMd5
params.description: • The MD5 digest value in base64. If you provide this, the client must provide this HTTP header with this same value in its request.

params.name: options.contentType
params.description: • If you provide this value, the client must provide this HTTP header set to the same value.

params.name: options.expires
params.description: • Timestamp (seconds since epoch) when this link will expire.

params.name: options.extensionHeaders
params.description: • If these headers are used, the server will check to make sure that the client provides matching values.

exceptions.description: if an expiration timestamp from the past is given.

methods.name: makePrivate
methods.description: Make a file private to the project and remove all other permissions. Set options.strict to true to make the file private to only the owner.

examples.code: file.makePrivate(function(err) {});

examples.caption: Set the file private so only the owner can see and modify it.
examples.code: file.makePrivate({ strict: true }, function(err) {});

params.name: options.strict
params.description: • If true, set the file to be private to only the owner user. Otherwise, it will be private to the project.

methods.name: makePublic
methods.description: Set a file to be publicly readable and maintain all previous permissions.

examples.code: file.makePublic(function(err) {});

methods.name: acl.owners
methods.description:
An object of convenience methods to add or delete owner ACL permissions for a given entity.

The supported methods include:

  • myFile.acl.owners.addAllAuthenticatedUsers
  • myFile.acl.owners.deleteAllAuthenticatedUsers
  • myFile.acl.owners.addAllUsers
  • myFile.acl.owners.deleteAllUsers
  • myFile.acl.owners.addDomain
  • myFile.acl.owners.deleteDomain
  • myFile.acl.owners.addGroup
  • myFile.acl.owners.deleteGroup
  • myFile.acl.owners.addProject
  • myFile.acl.owners.deleteProject
  • myFile.acl.owners.addUser
  • myFile.acl.owners.deleteUser

examples.caption: Add a user as an owner of a file.
examples.code: myFile.acl.owners.addUser('email@example.com', function(err, aclObject) {});

examples.caption: For reference, the above command is the same as running the following.

methods.name: acl.readers
methods.description:
An object of convenience methods to add or delete reader ACL permissions for a given entity.

The supported methods include:

  • myFile.acl.readers.addAllAuthenticatedUsers
  • myFile.acl.readers.deleteAllAuthenticatedUsers
  • myFile.acl.readers.addAllUsers
  • myFile.acl.readers.deleteAllUsers
  • myFile.acl.readers.addDomain
  • myFile.acl.readers.deleteDomain
  • myFile.acl.readers.addGroup
  • myFile.acl.readers.deleteGroup
  • myFile.acl.readers.addProject
  • myFile.acl.readers.deleteProject
  • myFile.acl.readers.addUser
  • myFile.acl.readers.deleteUser

examples.caption: Add a user as a reader of a file.
examples.code: myFile.acl.readers.addUser('email@example.com', function(err, aclObject) {});

examples.caption: For reference, the above command is the same as running the following.

methods.name: acl.writers
methods.description:
An object of convenience methods to add or delete writer ACL permissions for a given entity.

The supported methods include:

  • myFile.acl.writers.addAllAuthenticatedUsers
  • myFile.acl.writers.deleteAllAuthenticatedUsers
  • myFile.acl.writers.addAllUsers
  • myFile.acl.writers.deleteAllUsers
  • myFile.acl.writers.addDomain
  • myFile.acl.writers.deleteDomain
  • myFile.acl.writers.addGroup
  • myFile.acl.writers.deleteGroup
  • myFile.acl.writers.addProject
  • myFile.acl.writers.deleteProject
  • myFile.acl.writers.addUser
  • myFile.acl.writers.deleteUser

examples.caption: Add a user as a writer of a file.
examples.code: myFile.acl.writers.addUser('email@example.com', function(err, aclObject) {});

examples.caption: For reference, the above command is the same as running the following.
For file ACL operations, you can also specify a generation property. Here is how you would grant ownership permissions to a user on a specific revision of a file.

params.name: options.role
params.description: • Permissions allowed for the defined entity. See storage#acl.

params.name: options.generation
params.description: • File Objects Only Select a specific revision of this file (as opposed to the latest version, the default).

examples.caption: For file ACL operations, you can also specify a generation property.

params.name: options.generation
params.description: • File Objects Only Select a specific revision of this file (as opposed to the latest version, the default).

methods.name: acl.get
methods.description: Get access controls on a storage/bucket or storage/file. If an entity is omitted, you will receive an array of all applicable access controls.

examples.caption: Get all access controls.
For file ACL operations, you can also specify a generation property.

params.name: options
params.description: • Configuration object. If you want to receive a list of all access controls, pass the callback function as the only argument.

params.name: options.generation
params.description: • File Objects Only Select a specific revision of this file (as opposed to the latest version, the default).

examples.caption: For file ACL operations, you can also specify a generation property.

params.name: options.role
params.description: • Permissions allowed for the defined entity. See storage#acl.

params.name: options.generation
params.description: • File Objects Only Select a specific revision of this file (as opposed to the latest version, the default).
